issues.description: The problem statement and UML refer to a class named Stock (and show its methods), but the template repository provides an Inventory class that implements those methods while Stock.java is an empty file. The solution also uses Inventory as the type of the shared stock attribute (private static final Inventory stock). This class-name/type mismatch (Stock vs Inventory) is a structural inconsistency that will confuse students: the specification expects them to work with or modify Stock, yet the functional implementation is in Inventory and Stock.java is empty. Students may waste time searching for/implementing Stock methods that already exist under Inventory or be unsure which class they should extend/modify.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the class name consistent across artifacts. Either (A) rename the Inventory class to Stock in the template (and solution) so the Stock type the problem statement and UML reference exists and contains the documented methods; or (B) update the problem statement and UML to refer to Inventory instead of Stock and remove/replace the empty Stock.java file. Also remove or populate the empty Stock.java to avoid confusion. This keeps the structural API aligned with the exercise description and prevents students from being blocked by a class-name mismatch.

issues.description: The problem statement and UML describe a class named 'Stock' (the shared stock/inventory), but the starter code and reference solution implement this functionality in a class named 'Inventory'. There is even an (empty) Stock.java file in the template, which deepens the mismatch. This naming divergence breaks the direct mapping from the exercise text/UML to the codebase: students reading the problem will look for a Stock class and its methods, but the functioning implementation is provided under the name Inventory, causing confusion and wasted time locating the correct class.
issues.suggested_fix:
Align the identifier for the shared stock concept across all artifacts. Two possible fixes:
1) Rename Inventory.java (and its class) to Stock and update all references (in Starter and Solution) so the class and file are named Stock and implement the methods described in the problem/UML. Ensure the empty Stock.java is replaced by this implementation.
OR
2) Update the problem statement and UML to refer to 'Inventory' instead of 'Stock' (and clarify that the shared stock field type is Inventory). 
Either approach should be applied consistently so students can directly map the textual requirements/UML to the provided code.
